property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SDF Director is often used to oversee fairly simple, sequential workflows in which the director can determine the order of actor invocation from the workflow. Types of workflows that would run well under an SDF Director include processing and reformatting tabular data, converting one data type to another, and reading and plotting a series of data points. A workflow in which an image is read, processed (rotated, scaled, clipped, filtered, etc.), and then displayed, is also an example of a sequential workflow that requires a director simply to ensure that each actor fires in the proper order (i.e., that each actor executes only after it receives its required inputs).

The SDF Director is very efficient and will not tax system resources with overhead. However, this efficiency requires that certain conditions be met, namely that the data consumption and production rate of each actor in an SDF workflow be constant and declared. If an actor reads one piece of data and calculates and outputs a single result, it must always read and output a single token of data. This data rate cannot change during workflow execution and, in general, workflows that require dynamic scheduling and/or flow control cannot use this director. Additionally, the SDF Director has no understanding of passing time (at least by default), and actors that depend on a notion of time may not work as expected. For example, a TimedPlotter actor will plot all values at time zero when used in SDF.

By default, the SDF Director requires that all actors in its workflow be connected. Otherwise, the director cannot account for concurrency between disconnected workflow parts. Usually, a PN Director should be used for workflows that contain disconnected actors; however, the SDF Director's allowDisconnectedGraphs parameter may also be set to true. The SDF Director will then schedule each disconnected "island" independently. The director cannot infer the sequential relationship between disconnected actors (i.e., nothing forces the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another). However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF model indicate an error.

Because SDF Directors schedule actors to fire only after they receive their inputs, workflows that require loops (feeding an actor's output back into its input port for further processing) can cause "deadlock" errors. The deadlock errors occur because the actor depends on its own output value as an initial input. To fix this problem, use a SampleDelay actor to generate and inject an initial input value into the workflow.

The SDF Director determines the order in which actors execute and how many times each actor needs to be fired to complete a single iteration of the workflow. This schedule is calculated BEFORE the director begins to iterate the workflow. Because the SDF Director calculates a schedule in advance, it is quite efficient. However, SDF workflows must be static. In other words, the same number of tokens must be consumed/produced at every iteration of the workflow. Workflows that require dynamic control structures, such as a BooleanSwitch actor that sends output on one of two ports depending on the value of a 'control', cannot be used with an SDF Director because the number of tokens on each output can change for each execution.

Unless otherwise specified, the SDF Director assumes that each actor consumes and produces exactly one token per channel on each firing. Actors that do not follow the one-token-per-channel firing convention (e.g., Repeat or Ramp) must declare the number of tokens they produce or consume via the appropriate parameters.

The number of times a workflow is iterated is controlled by the director's iterations parameter. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

The amount of data processed by an SDF workflow is a function of both the number of times the workflow iterates and the value of the director's vectorizationFactor parameter. The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

The SDF Director has several advanced parameters that are generally only relevant when an SDF workflow contains composite components. In most cases the period, timeResolution, synchronizeToRealTime, allowRateChanges, timeResolution, and constrainBufferSizes parameters can be left at their default values.

For more information about the SDF Director, see the Ptolemy documentation (http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign3-domains/ptIIdesign3-domains.pdf).

property.name: prop:allowDisconnectedGraphs
property.configure: Specify whether to allow disconnected actors in the workflow (by default, all actors are required to be connected). If disconnected actors are permitted, the SDF Director will schedule each disconnected 'island' independently. Nothing "forces" the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another. However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF workflow indicate an error.

property.name: prop:allowRateChanges
property.configure: Specify whether dynamic rate changes are permitted or not. By default, rate changes are not permitted, and the director will perform a check to disallow such workflows. If the parameter is selected, then workflows that require rate parameters to be modified during execution are valid, and the SDF Director will dynamically compute a new schedule at runtime. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:timeResolution
property.configure: The time precision used by this director. All time values are rounded to the nearest multiple of this number. The value is a double that defaults to "1E-10" (which is 10-10). This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:constrainBufferSizes
property.configure: Specify whether buffer sizes are fixed. By default, buffers are fixed, and attempts to write to the buffer that cause the buffer to exceed its scheduled size result in an error. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

property.name: prop:vectorizationFactor
property.configure: The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

property.name: prop:synchronizeToRealTime
property.configure: Specify whether the execution should synchronize to real time or not. By default, the director does not synchronize to real time. If synchronize is selected, the director will only process the workflow when elapsed real time matches the product of the period parameter and the iteration count. Note: if the period parameter has a value of 0.0 (the default), then selecting this parameter has no effect. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:period
property.configure: The time period of each iteration. The value is a double that defaults to 0.0, which means that the director does not increment workflow time. If the value greater than 0.0, the actor will increment workflow time each time it fires. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: text
property.value: The Single Species GARP Model actor is a special higher Order Composite (HOC) actor designed to execute the workflow inside it multiple times. Right-click the actor and select "Open Actor" to see details.

property.name: text
property.value:
This Ecological Niche Model (ENM) workflow predicts the distribution of multiple species (Mephitis mephitis, a striped skunk, and Zapus, a mouse, in the sample data set) based on collected occurrence locations and environmental data (IPCC climate data and Hydro1 topographical data). The workflow uses the GARP (Genetic Algorithm for Rule Set Production) algorithm to generate predictions, which are then tested for accuracy. The most accurate predictions are used to project the species' distribution onto a complete map of North and South America. Predictions are made using both historical and future IPCC climate data.
For more information, double-click the Documentation button, or right-click the Workflow canvas and select Documentation from the drop-down menu.
NOTE: In the interest of minimizing run-times, the example workflow iterates the GARP algorithm only 10 times for each species, which is insufficient for reliable statistics. In addition, only some of the future climate data are processed by the workflow.
Dan Higgins - NCEAS Sept 29, 2006

property.name: description
property.value:
The deceptively simple top level of the GARP_MultipleSpecies-V.xml workflow consists of two composite actors: one that iterates over a list of species and their associated occurrence point files, and a second that contains a set of nested sub-workflows that comprise a full ENM workflow (i.e., the GARP_SingleSpecies_BestRuleSet-IV.xml workflow).

Together, the two composite actors form an Ecological Niche Model (ENM) workflow that predicts the distribution of multiple species (Mephitis mephitis, a striped skunk, and Zapus, a mouse, in the sample data set) based on collected occurrence locations and environmental data (IPCC climate data and Hydro1 topographical data). The workflow uses the GARP (Genetic Algorithm for Rule Set Production) algorithm to generate predictions, which are then tested for accuracy. The most accurate predictions are used to project the species' distribution onto a complete map of North and South America. Predictions are made using both historical and future IPCC climate data.

NOTE: In the interest of minimizing run-times, the example workflow iterates the GARP algorithm only 10 times, which is insufficient for reliable statistics. In addition, only some of the future climate data are processed by the workflow.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins - NCEAS

property.name: Species_List (parameter)
property.value: The name of a text file containing pairs of species' names and associated occurrence data. Pairs are comma separated, one pair per line. Occurrence data are saved as a text file in the form of latitude/longitude pairs, also comma separated, one pair per line.

property.name: Species_List_Path (parameter)
property.value: The directory in which the workflow data are stored.

property.name: MinimumSpecimenCount (parameter)
property.value: The minimum number of occurrence points for each species. In the example workflow, the parameter has a value of 10; any species that has fewer than 10 occurrence points will not be run by the workflow.

property.name: text
property.value: ATTENTION ENM USERS: As of Kepler release 1.0 we have worked hard to make the ENM workflows as stable as possible. Due to several complexities involving the implementation of GARP in the workfows, there are some known bugs that may cause the workflow to not function correctly, terminate early or crash Kepler altogether. We will continue working on these problems after release 1.0. Please see bug 3266 at http://bugzilla.ecoinformatics.org for a full description of these problems.

property.name: description
property.value:
This ENM sub-workflow prepares species and location data for use with the Single Species GARP Model sub-workflow. The workflow reads a file containing pairs of species' names and their associated occurrence location data. The workflow checks to make sure that the data are acceptable, and then outputs a series of species names and occurrence data for further processing.

The Species_List_Path and Species_List parameters, specified in the top-level workflow, provide the location and name of the text file that contains the species and occurrence data. This file contains a list of pairs of species' names and assocociated occurrence data. Pairs are comma separated, one pair per line. Occurrence data are saved as a text file in the form of latitude/longitude pairs, also comma separated, one pair per line. The MinimumSpecimenCount parameter, also specified by the containing workflow, specifies the minimum number of occurrence points for each species. In the example workflow, the parameter has a value of 10; any species that has fewer than 10 occurrence points will not be run by the workflow.

The sub-workflow uses three Expression actors (Path, FileName, and minimumCnt) to pass the file name and path of the occurrence data, as well as the required minimum number of occurrence points, to a customized RExpression actor. The RExpression actor iterates over the list of species, locates the occurrence data file, reads through the data, and checks the number of occurrence points against the minimum threshold. The RExpression actor saves the "valid" species to a new index file: The species name and the path to its occurrence data set are separated by a comma; each species is saved on a separate line.

The RExpression actor outputs the file path of the revised species data index to a Line Reader actor that reads the file and outputs each line as a string. The output strings are split by the String Splitter actor, which splits strings at a character or characters specified by its Regular expression parameter. In this example, the character is a comma, ",". The actor outputs an array containing the split segments (e.g., { Mephitis,digir_data_mephitis.dat}). A relation is used to branch the actor's output so that it can be sent to multiple places in the workflow, in this case, to two Expression actors: SpeciesName and LocationFilename.

The SpeciesName and LocationFilename actors use the Ptolemy expression language to access the appropriate data. lineS(0), the value of the SpeciesName actor, refers to the first element in the array passed to the actor via its lines port. lineS(1), the value of the LocationFilename actor, refers to the second element in the array. The species name and the path to its occurrence data are output to the Single Species GARP Model actor, which models the data and generates the predicted species distribution maps.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins - NCEAS

property.name: Species_Name (port)
property.value: The name of the species to run through the Single Species GARP Model sub-workflow.

property.name: Location_Filename (port)
property.value: The name of the text file that contains occurrence location data for each species, specified as longitude/latitude pairs, one pair per line.

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Wibke Sudholt

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringSplitter actor reads a string and splits it into segments at specified points. The actor outputs the segments as an array of strings.

The actor separates the input string at points specified by the regular expression parameter. For example, if the input string is a URL (http://www.mysite.com/home/archive/stuff) and the Regular expression parameter is /, the actor will output the following array {"http:", "", "home", "archive", "stuff"}. For more information about regular expressions, see http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/extra/regex/index.html.

property.name: port:string
property.configure: An input port that accepts a string.

property.name: port:array
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts an array of string segments.

property.name: prop:Regular expression
property.configure: A regular expression used to identify the points at which the actor should break the string. For more information about regular expressions, see http://java.sun.com/docs/books/tutorial/extra/regex/index.html.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: null

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The LineReader actor reads a file or URL, one line at a time, and outputs each line as a string.

Kepler contains several actors used to read and output files in different ways. To read and output a file as a single string, use the FileReader or SimpleFileReader actor. To read and output a specified section of the file, use the SegmentFileReader actor.

Use the numberOfLinesToSkip parameter to optionally specify the number of lines to skip at the beginning of the file.

When the end of the file is reached, the actor will cease firing. With some directors (such as SDF), the model will stop executing when the actor does. With other directors (such as DE), the actor will cease firing, but the model will continue to execute.

To reset the LineReader to start again at the beginning of the file, use a modal model with a reset-enabled transition. For more information about modal models, see the User Manual.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a string for each line of the input file.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: port:endOfFile
property.configure: An output port that indicates whether or not the end of the file has been reached. If the end of the file has been reached, the port will produce a true value and the actor will cease firing. Otherwise, the value is false.

property.name: prop:numberOfLinesToSkip
property.configure: The number of lines to skip at the beginning of the file or URL. 0 is specified by default. The value of this parameter must be non-negative.

property.name: prop:fileOrURL
property.configure: The file name or URL of the file to be read. See FileParameter for more information about specifying file names.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Dan Higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The RExpression actor runs an R script or function. Input and output port are created by the user and correspond to R variables used in the specified R script. The actor outputs the result of the evaluated script.

The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

Kepler contains a number of preconfigured R-actors: Barplot, Boxplot, Scatterplot, Summary, RandomNormal, RandomUniform, Correlation, LinearModel, Regression, RMean, RMedian, RQuantile, and SummaryStatistics.

property.name: port:graphicsFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated graph of the results.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: prop:Rcwd
property.configure: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: prop:displayGraphicsOutput
property.configure: Select to display the plot once the actor has generated it.

property.name: prop:graphicsFormat
property.configure: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: prop:numXPixels
property.configure: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:numYPixels
property.configure: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: prop:graphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: prop:save_nosave
property.configure: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.configure: null

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Constant actor outputs a constant, which is specified by the value parameter. By default, the actor outputs the integer 1.

The actor can be used to output other types of values, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The actor' s output type matches the type of the specified value.

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the specified constant. By default, the output is 1.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the Constant actor. By default, the value is the integer token 1. The value can be set to another type, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The output type matches the type of the value specified here.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SDF Director is often used to oversee fairly simple, sequential workflows in which the director can determine the order of actor invocation from the workflow. Types of workflows that would run well under an SDF Director include processing and reformatting tabular data, converting one data type to another, and reading and plotting a series of data points. A workflow in which an image is read, processed (rotated, scaled, clipped, filtered, etc.), and then displayed, is also an example of a sequential workflow that requires a director simply to ensure that each actor fires in the proper order (i.e., that each actor executes only after it receives its required inputs).

The SDF Director is very efficient and will not tax system resources with overhead. However, this efficiency requires that certain conditions be met, namely that the data consumption and production rate of each actor in an SDF workflow be constant and declared. If an actor reads one piece of data and calculates and outputs a single result, it must always read and output a single token of data. This data rate cannot change during workflow execution and, in general, workflows that require dynamic scheduling and/or flow control cannot use this director. Additionally, the SDF Director has no understanding of passing time (at least by default), and actors that depend on a notion of time may not work as expected. For example, a TimedPlotter actor will plot all values at time zero when used in SDF.

By default, the SDF Director requires that all actors in its workflow be connected. Otherwise, the director cannot account for concurrency between disconnected workflow parts. Usually, a PN Director should be used for workflows that contain disconnected actors; however, the SDF Director's allowDisconnectedGraphs parameter may also be set to true. The SDF Director will then schedule each disconnected "island" independently. The director cannot infer the sequential relationship between disconnected actors (i.e., nothing forces the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another). However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF model indicate an error.

Because SDF Directors schedule actors to fire only after they receive their inputs, workflows that require loops (feeding an actor's output back into its input port for further processing) can cause "deadlock" errors. The deadlock errors occur because the actor depends on its own output value as an initial input. To fix this problem, use a SampleDelay actor to generate and inject an initial input value into the workflow.

The SDF Director determines the order in which actors execute and how many times each actor needs to be fired to complete a single iteration of the workflow. This schedule is calculated BEFORE the director begins to iterate the workflow. Because the SDF Director calculates a schedule in advance, it is quite efficient. However, SDF workflows must be static. In other words, the same number of tokens must be consumed/produced at every iteration of the workflow. Workflows that require dynamic control structures, such as a BooleanSwitch actor that sends output on one of two ports depending on the value of a 'control', cannot be used with an SDF Director because the number of tokens on each output can change for each execution.

Unless otherwise specified, the SDF Director assumes that each actor consumes and produces exactly one token per channel on each firing. Actors that do not follow the one-token-per-channel firing convention (e.g., Repeat or Ramp) must declare the number of tokens they produce or consume via the appropriate parameters.

The number of times a workflow is iterated is controlled by the director's iterations parameter. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

The amount of data processed by an SDF workflow is a function of both the number of times the workflow iterates and the value of the director's vectorizationFactor parameter. The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

The SDF Director has several advanced parameters that are generally only relevant when an SDF workflow contains composite components. In most cases the period, timeResolution, synchronizeToRealTime, allowRateChanges, timeResolution, and constrainBufferSizes parameters can be left at their default values.

For more information about the SDF Director, see the Ptolemy documentation (http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign3-domains/ptIIdesign3-domains.pdf).

property.name: prop:allowDisconnectedGraphs
property.configure: Specify whether to allow disconnected actors in the workflow (by default, all actors are required to be connected). If disconnected actors are permitted, the SDF Director will schedule each disconnected 'island' independently. Nothing "forces" the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another. However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF workflow indicate an error.

property.name: prop:allowRateChanges
property.configure: Specify whether dynamic rate changes are permitted or not. By default, rate changes are not permitted, and the director will perform a check to disallow such workflows. If the parameter is selected, then workflows that require rate parameters to be modified during execution are valid, and the SDF Director will dynamically compute a new schedule at runtime. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:timeResolution
property.configure: The time precision used by this director. All time values are rounded to the nearest multiple of this number. The value is a double that defaults to "1E-10" (which is 10-10). This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:constrainBufferSizes
property.configure: Specify whether buffer sizes are fixed. By default, buffers are fixed, and attempts to write to the buffer that cause the buffer to exceed its scheduled size result in an error. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

property.name: prop:vectorizationFactor
property.configure: The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

property.name: prop:synchronizeToRealTime
property.configure: Specify whether the execution should synchronize to real time or not. By default, the director does not synchronize to real time. If synchronize is selected, the director will only process the workflow when elapsed real time matches the product of the period parameter and the iteration count. Note: if the period parameter has a value of 0.0 (the default), then selecting this parameter has no effect. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:period
property.configure: The time period of each iteration. The value is a double that defaults to 0.0, which means that the director does not increment workflow time. If the value greater than 0.0, the actor will increment workflow time each time it fires. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: text
property.value: NOTE: Each iteration requires 10-20 seconds on a typical desktop PC.

property.name: text
property.value:
This Ecological Niche Model (ENM) sub-workflow predicts the distribution of species based on collected occurrence locations and environmental data (IPCC climate data and Hydro1 topographical data). Species' names and associated occurrence data are passed to the workflow via the Get Species/Location Information sub-workflow. The workflow uses the GARP (Genetic Algorithm for Rule Set Production) algorithm to generate predictions, which are then tested for accuracy. The most accurate predictions are used to project the species' distribution onto a complete map of North and South America. Predictions are made using both historical and future IPCC climate data.
For more information, double-click the Documentation button, or right-click the Workflow canvas and select Documentation from the drop-down menu.
NOTE: In the interest of minimizing run-times, the example workflow iterates the GARP algorithm only 10 times, which is insufficient for reliable statistics. In addition, only some of the future climate data are processed by the workflow.
Dan Higgins - NCEAS

property.name: description
property.value:
This Ecological Niche Model (ENM) sub-workflow predicts the distribution of species based on collected occurrence points and environmental data (IPCC climate data and Hydro1 topographical data). The workflow uses the GARP (Genetic Algorithm for Rule Set Production) algorithm to generate predictions, which are then tested for accuracy. The most accurate predictions are used to project the species' distribution onto a complete map of North and South America. Predictions are made using both historical and future IPCC climate data.

The name of each species to run, along with associated occurrence data, is passed to the workflow via the Get Species Occurrence/Location information sub-workflow. The occurrence data is passed to the Calculate Best Rulesets sub-workflow, which reads the occurrence data as well as environmental data used to generate the predicted species distribution. Environmental data must have previously been processed into "bundled" layers that have the same geographic extent and resolution. Occurrence data must be in the form of a set of occurrence points for the species, one occurrence point per line, listed as tab-delimited longitude/latitude combinations. See Ecological Niche Modeling in Kepler for more information about how to prepare data for use with ENM workflows.

The Calculate Best Rulesets sub-workflow uses the GARP algorithm to sample the environmental data and generate predicted species' distributions. GARP is a stochastic algorithm; each time it is run on a given dataset, it will generate a different model. Typically, the algorithm is run hundreds of times for a given species dataset, the results are analyzed to determine the best models, and the results of the best models are compiled and returned. The number_Of_Iterations parameter specifies the number of times to iterate the GARP algorithm, and the NumBest parameter specifies the number of best predictions to select and combine into the final prediction.

The Calculate Best Rulesets actor outputs an array of the best GARP models, which are stored as *.asc grid files. In the example workflow, the GARP algorithm is used to predict species distributions for North and South America, and opening any of the generated *.asc best prediction files with an image processing application, such as ImageJ, will display a map of the Western Hemisphere with the predicted distribution denoted by shades of color.

The AddGrids actor reads the array of best prediction *.asc files and merges them into a single file. Grid cells that have the most predictions of presence across the subset of best models have the highest probability of species occurrence. Thus, cell values are added for all pixels in the input file list. The AddGrids actor outputs the name of the merged file (which is specified via the Output file path and name actor). The IJMacro actor displays the final prediction.

In addition to the array of *.asc files, the Calculate Best Rulesets actor also outputs an array of the rulesets used to generate the predicted species' distributions. The rulesets are generated by the GARP algorithm and are based on the sampled environmental layers. A rule might be something like: "If annual precipitation is more than 5 mm and less than 12 mm then the species is present." Each generated ruleset is saved to a file, and the rulesets used to calculate the best species distributions are output to two places (a relation is used to branch the data): the Save_Results_in_Zip sub-workflow, which zips the files so that they can be easily stored and shared, and the Future_Climate_Models sub-workflow, which generates predicted species' distributions using IPCC future climate change data. For more information about these sub-workflows, right-click the actor icons and select "Documentation."

Any species can be run through this workflow simply by updating the Species_Name parameter with the new species name, and changing the I-DataPoints actor to point to the data file that contains the occurrence points for the new species. To update the I-DataPoints actor, double-click it, and edit the value parameter. Note that the value references DataDirectory, a parameter defined on the Workflow canvas. property("KEPLER") is used to point to the directory in which Kepler is installed.

NOTE: In the interest of minimizing run-times, the example workflow iterates the GARP algorithm only 10 times, which is insufficient for reliable statistics. In addition, only some of the future climate data are processed by the workflow.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins

property.name: Species_Name (port-parameter)
property.value: The name of the species for which a predicted distribution is being generated. Species' names are passed to the workflow by the Get Species/Location information sub-workflow.

property.name: Location_Filename (port-parameter)
property.value: The name of the text file containing species' occurrence data. Occurrence data are passed to the workflow by the Get Species/Location information sub-workflow.

property.name: number_Of_Iterations (parameter)
property.value: The number of times to iterate the GARP algorithm. GARP is a stochastic algorithm; each time it is run on a given dataset, it will generate a different model. Typically, the algorithm is run hundreds of times for a given species data set. Each iteration requires 10-20 seconds on a typical desktop PC

property.name: DataDirectory (parameter)
property.value: The directory in which the workflow data are stored.

property.name: NumBest (parameter)
property.value: NumBest The number of best GARP predictions to select and then combine to create the final prediction. Typically, the GARP algorithm is run hundreds of times for a given species data set, the results are analyzed to determine the best models, and the number of "best" models specified by this parameter are compiled and returned.

This workflow uses the best models generated using historical climate datasets to predict species distribution under future climate change scenarios. The workflow reads an array of the best GARP rulesets, prepares environmental layer sets containing future climate data, generates a prediction, and outputs a map of each scenario.
For more information, double-click the Documentation button, or right-click the Workflow canvas and select "Documentation" from the drop-down menu.
NOTE: This sub-workflow is designed to create predictions for multiple future climate scenarios (e.g., IPCC_2020, IPCC_2050, etc); however, the current workflow does not fully demonstrate this potential as only the IPCC_2020 future climate dataset has been processed. In order to actually predict results for 2050, the "climateList.txt" containing references to the data set for 2050 must be updated to point to the correct data. Right-click the Workflow canvas and select "Documentation" for more information.

property.name: description
property.value:
The Future_Climate_Models sub-workflow uses the best species' distribution models generated using historical climate datasets to predict species distributions under future climate change scenarios. The workflow reads an array of the best GARP rulesets, prepares environmental layer sets containing future climate data instead of historical data, generates a prediction, and outputs a map of each scenario.

The sub-workflow is triggered by the arrival of an array of the best rulesets, output by the Calculate Best Rulesets sub-workflow. The rulesets are created by the GARP Algorithm, and contain rules about climate conditions under which a species might survive.

The array is passed to a Repeat actor, which is used to control the workflow iterations. Its numberOfTimes parameter is set to 2, instructing the workflow to repeat twice. The data are then branched via a relation: one set is fed to a Ramp actor (used like a "for" loop); the other is input to the Create Best ASC Maps sub-workflow, which generates the predicted species distribution maps.

Preparing environmental layer sets for future climate predictions consists of four basic steps:

  1. Reading a list of climate scenarios to run (e.g., 2020, 2050, etc)
  2. Replacing historical data with future data for each scenario
  3. Specifying a file name and path to apply to each revised dataset
  4. Constructing a new *.dxl file containing the future climate layers for use with GARP

The workflow uses two Expression actors (MappingFile_Name and NewLayers_Name) to reference the name and location of the datasets, both of which are specified by workflow parameters: the NewClimateFiles parameter contains an array of text files that contain future climate data; the NewClimateNames parameter contains an array of future climate data set names.

Note that the NewClimateFiles for both IPCC_2020 and IPCC_2050 is "NewClimate.txt." The "NewClimate.txt" file specifies a list of text files that contain future climate data that should replace the historical data for the new prediction. Normally, each future scenario would have a unique dataset file; the example workflow uses "NewClimate.txt" for both scenarios because the data for the 2050 IPCC predictions have not yet been processed for use with the ENM workflow. In a real workflow run, the dataset for 2050 would be a unique file.

Note: the climate variables (e.g., temperature, rainfall, etc) in the historical and future datasets must be specified in the same order.

The workflow's Expression actor constructs the path to the future climate data set. The actor references the DataDirectory parameter defined by the containing workflow (property("KEPLER")+"/outreach/resources/data/garp") as well as the value passed to its "in" port (e.g., NewClimate.txt), and combines the two to form a path. This path is passed to a customized RExpression actor, which does the actual data replacement and generates a new *.dxl file containing the future climate data. The Expression2 actor constructs a name for the new *.dxl file.

The RExpression actor reads the path to the new climate data, the path to the existing *.dxl climate data used by the historical prediction, and the name to use for the updated *.dxl file. The actor uses a customized R-script to map the future data to the historical data, and outputs the name of the new *.dxl file. (The GARP algorithm requires that each environmental layer be converted to a custom binary format (*.raw), and that information about the layer set is summarized in a text file (*.dxl).

The new environmental layer set is passed to the Create Best ASC Maps sub-workflow, which outputs an array of the best predictions.

The AddGrids actor reads the array of best prediction files (*.asc) and merges them into a single file. Grid cells that have the most predictions of presence across the subset of best models have the highest probability of species occurrence. Thus, cell values are added for all pixels in the input file list. The AddGrids actor outputs the name of the merged file (the name is specified via the Expression4 actor). The IJMacro actor displays the final prediction.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins -NCEAS

property.name: FutureClimateModels_File (parameter)
property.value: The location of the file that contains a list of future climate scenarios to run (e.g., 2020, 2050, etc)

property.name: NewClimateFiles (parameter)
property.value: The names of the text files containing the future climate data. Values are specified as an array of file names (e.g., {"NewClimate.txt","NewClimate.txt"}). Note that the example workflow uses the same data file for both 2020 and 2050 datasets. To generate a true prediction, the second element in the NewClimateFiles array must be updated to point to a file containing 2050 data.

property.name: NewClimateNames (parameter)
property.value: The names of the future climate data sets. Values are specified as an array of names (e.g., {"IPCC_2020","IPCC_2050"})

property.name: ClimateCnt (parameter)
property.value: The number of climate data sets to run. The parameter value references the length of the NewClimateFiles array (in the example, the value is 2).

property.name: Trigger (port)
property.value: The sub-workflow is triggered by the arrival of an array of the best rulesets via this port.

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.configure: null

property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.configure:
The RExpression actor runs an R script or function. Input and output port are created by the user and correspond to R variables used in the specified R script. The actor outputs the result of the evaluated script.

The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

Kepler contains a number of preconfigured R-actors: Barplot, Boxplot, Scatterplot, Summary, RandomNormal, RandomUniform, Correlation, LinearModel, Regression, RMean, RMedian, RQuantile, and SummaryStatistics.

property.name: port:graphicsFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated graph of the results.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: prop:Rcwd
property.configure: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: prop:displayGraphicsOutput
property.configure: Select to display the plot once the actor has generated it.

property.name: prop:graphicsFormat
property.configure: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: prop:numXPixels
property.configure: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:numYPixels
property.configure: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: prop:graphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: prop:save_nosave
property.configure: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.configure:
The Repeat actor reads and repeats a "block" of tokens (i.e., one or more tokens of any type). The actor outputs the block a user-specified number of times.

Specify the block size with the blockSize parameter and the number of times to repeat the block with the numberOfTimes parameter. Note: because the actor reads multiple input tokens at each iteration, it causes a sample rate increase by a factor of numberOfTimes, and hence affects the number of invocations of downstream actors.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts tokens of any type. Specify the number of tokens to read at each iteration with the blockSize parameter.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the block of tokens the specified number of times. Specify the number of times to repeat the output with the numberOfTimes parameter.

property.name: prop:blockSize
property.configure: The number of tokens in a block. The value is an integer and must be greater than zero. The default is 1.

property.name: prop:numberOfTimes
property.configure: The repetition factor. The value is an integer and must be greater than 0. The default is 2.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SDF Director is often used to oversee fairly simple, sequential workflows in which the director can determine the order of actor invocation from the workflow. Types of workflows that would run well under an SDF Director include processing and reformatting tabular data, converting one data type to another, and reading and plotting a series of data points. A workflow in which an image is read, processed (rotated, scaled, clipped, filtered, etc.), and then displayed, is also an example of a sequential workflow that requires a director simply to ensure that each actor fires in the proper order (i.e., that each actor executes only after it receives its required inputs).

The SDF Director is very efficient and will not tax system resources with overhead. However, this efficiency requires that certain conditions be met, namely that the data consumption and production rate of each actor in an SDF workflow be constant and declared. If an actor reads one piece of data and calculates and outputs a single result, it must always read and output a single token of data. This data rate cannot change during workflow execution and, in general, workflows that require dynamic scheduling and/or flow control cannot use this director. Additionally, the SDF Director has no understanding of passing time (at least by default), and actors that depend on a notion of time may not work as expected. For example, a TimedPlotter actor will plot all values at time zero when used in SDF.

By default, the SDF Director requires that all actors in its workflow be connected. Otherwise, the director cannot account for concurrency between disconnected workflow parts. Usually, a PN Director should be used for workflows that contain disconnected actors; however, the SDF Director's allowDisconnectedGraphs parameter may also be set to true. The SDF Director will then schedule each disconnected "island" independently. The director cannot infer the sequential relationship between disconnected actors (i.e., nothing forces the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another). However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF model indicate an error.

Because SDF Directors schedule actors to fire only after they receive their inputs, workflows that require loops (feeding an actor's output back into its input port for further processing) can cause "deadlock" errors. The deadlock errors occur because the actor depends on its own output value as an initial input. To fix this problem, use a SampleDelay actor to generate and inject an initial input value into the workflow.

The SDF Director determines the order in which actors execute and how many times each actor needs to be fired to complete a single iteration of the workflow. This schedule is calculated BEFORE the director begins to iterate the workflow. Because the SDF Director calculates a schedule in advance, it is quite efficient. However, SDF workflows must be static. In other words, the same number of tokens must be consumed/produced at every iteration of the workflow. Workflows that require dynamic control structures, such as a BooleanSwitch actor that sends output on one of two ports depending on the value of a 'control', cannot be used with an SDF Director because the number of tokens on each output can change for each execution.

Unless otherwise specified, the SDF Director assumes that each actor consumes and produces exactly one token per channel on each firing. Actors that do not follow the one-token-per-channel firing convention (e.g., Repeat or Ramp) must declare the number of tokens they produce or consume via the appropriate parameters.

The number of times a workflow is iterated is controlled by the director's iterations parameter. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

The amount of data processed by an SDF workflow is a function of both the number of times the workflow iterates and the value of the director's vectorizationFactor parameter. The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

The SDF Director has several advanced parameters that are generally only relevant when an SDF workflow contains composite components. In most cases the period, timeResolution, synchronizeToRealTime, allowRateChanges, timeResolution, and constrainBufferSizes parameters can be left at their default values.

For more information about the SDF Director, see the Ptolemy documentation (http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign3-domains/ptIIdesign3-domains.pdf).

property.name: prop:allowDisconnectedGraphs
property.configure: Specify whether to allow disconnected actors in the workflow (by default, all actors are required to be connected). If disconnected actors are permitted, the SDF Director will schedule each disconnected 'island' independently. Nothing "forces" the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another. However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF workflow indicate an error.

property.name: prop:allowRateChanges
property.configure: Specify whether dynamic rate changes are permitted or not. By default, rate changes are not permitted, and the director will perform a check to disallow such workflows. If the parameter is selected, then workflows that require rate parameters to be modified during execution are valid, and the SDF Director will dynamically compute a new schedule at runtime. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:timeResolution
property.configure: The time precision used by this director. All time values are rounded to the nearest multiple of this number. The value is a double that defaults to "1E-10" (which is 10-10). This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:constrainBufferSizes
property.configure: Specify whether buffer sizes are fixed. By default, buffers are fixed, and attempts to write to the buffer that cause the buffer to exceed its scheduled size result in an error. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

property.name: prop:vectorizationFactor
property.configure: The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

property.name: prop:synchronizeToRealTime
property.configure: Specify whether the execution should synchronize to real time or not. By default, the director does not synchronize to real time. If synchronize is selected, the director will only process the workflow when elapsed real time matches the product of the period parameter and the iteration count. Note: if the period parameter has a value of 0.0 (the default), then selecting this parameter has no effect. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:period
property.configure: The time period of each iteration. The value is a double that defaults to 0.0, which means that the director does not increment workflow time. If the value greater than 0.0, the actor will increment workflow time each time it fires. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Yuhong Xiong

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SequenceToArray actor reads a sequence of elements and bundles them into a single array, which the actor outputs.

The actor can accept inputs of any one type (int, double, etc.) The type must be consistent. The number of elements to be bundled is specified by the arrayLength parameter or port.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts a sequence of input elements. Elements may be of any one type (int, double, etc). The type must be consistent.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts an assembled array. The type of the array elements matches that of the input values.

property.name: port:arrayLength
property.configure: An input port that accepts the size of the output array. The default is the integer 1.

property.name: prop:arrayLength
property.configure: The size of the output array. The default is the integer 1.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: null

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Constant actor outputs a constant, which is specified by the value parameter. By default, the actor outputs the integer 1.

The actor can be used to output other types of values, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The actor' s output type matches the type of the specified value.

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the specified constant. By default, the output is 1.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the Constant actor. By default, the value is the integer token 1. The value can be set to another type, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The output type matches the type of the value specified here.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Chad Berkeley, Dan Higgins, NCEAS, UC Santa Barbara

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The GARPPrediction actor predicts the distribution of a species in given locations based on a predefined rule set. The actor outputs a bitmapped image (a map) representing species presence or absence with different pixel values (e.g., different colors).

The input rule set is usually passed to the actor by the GARPAlgorithm actor, which creates the rule set and outputs it in the proper format. Input locations with environmental data, or "environmental layers", are passed to the GARPPrediction actor in a summary xml file (*.dxl).

The actor outputs the predicted species distribution in two formats: bitmap and ASCII raster grid. Both files contain the same information. The bitmap file is often more easily displayed; the ASCII raster grid can be used by the GARPSummary actor to test the accuracy of the predicted distribution.

The actor requires libgarp.so (on linux systems) or garp.dll and libexpat.dll (on Windows systems). Currently, the actor does not work on MacOSX systems.

GARP (Genetic Algorithm for Rule Set Production) is a genetic algorithm that creates an ecological niche model representing the environmental conditions where a species would be able to maintain populations. For more information about GARP, see http://www.lifemapper.org/desktopgarp/.

property.name: port:ruleSetFilename
property.configure: An input port that accepts the file name of the file containing the rule set data (usually the output of a GarpAlgorithm actor).

property.name: port:layersetFilename
property.configure: An input port that accepts the file name of the location and environmental information (the environmental layers). The file is a *.dxl file, which summarizes a set of spatial data files.

property.name: port:outputBMPFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated bitmap file after the file has been created. The bitmap file contains the same information as the ASCII grid file, but in a more easily displayed raster format.

property.name: port:outputBMP
property.configure: The file name for the output bitmapped file (*.bmp).

property.name: port:outputASCIIFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the ASCII grid file containing the predicted species distribution. The port fires after the file has been created.

property.name: port:outputASCII
property.configure: The file name for the output ASCII grid file (*.asc).

property.name: prop:ruleSetFilenameParameter
property.configure: The file name of the file containing the rule set data (usually the output of a GarpAlgorithm actor).

property.name: prop:outputASCIIParameter
property.configure: The file name to be used for the output ASCII grid file (*.asc).

property.name: prop:outputBMPParameter
property.configure: The file name to be used for the output bitmap file (*.bmp)

property.name: prop:layersetFilenameParameter
property.configure: The file name of the location and environmental data. The file is a *.dxl file, which summarizes a set of spatial data files that contain environmental data.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: unknown

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The ArrayToSequence actor outputs the individual values of an array as a sequence of tokens.

The actor can accept an array with any element type (e.g., int, double, etc.). Each time the actor fires, it reads and disassembles one array and outputs a sequence of values.

The arrayLength parameter can be used to specify the length of the source array. If the enforceArrayLength parameter is selected, then the actor will only accept arrays of the specified length. The enforceArrayLength parameter should be selected if using an SDF director. If using other directors, such as DE or PN, the enforceArrayLength parameter can be deselected, in which case the arrayLength parameter is ignored.

The ArrayToSequence actor is similar to the ArrayToElements actor, except that it outputs values as a sequence via a single output port. The ArrayToElements actor outputs individual values on multiple channels of the output port. Use the ArrayAccumulator actor to convert an array into a single string, where each value is separated by a specified separator.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a sequence of the disassembled array values.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts an array of elements of any type.

property.name: prop:enforceArrayLength
property.configure: Specify whether or not to enforce the arrayLength parameter. By default, the arrayLength is enforced, and the actor will only accept arrays of the specified length.

property.name: prop:arrayLength
property.configure: The size of the input array. The default is 1.

property.configure: null
