property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: dan higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The AddGrids actor reads two or more geospatial image files, merges the files by adding the cell values, and outputs the name of the merged file.

The gridFilenameArray port accepts an array of image file names. The extent and cell size of the merged file will match that of the first input file. The name of the merged file is specified via the mergedGridFilename port.

The actor's primary purpose is to combine stochastic files to give a spatial distribution where more probable cells have larger values. Thus, cell values are added for all pixels in the input file list.

The AddGrids actor is similar to the MergeGrids actor, except that AddGrids actor can be used to merge multiple files, while MergeGrids can merge only two.

property.name: port:mergedGridFileResult
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the merged raster file (acts as a trigger when addition is complete).

property.name: port:mergedGridFileName
property.configure: An input port that accepts the name given to the resulting output file

property.name: port:gridFilenameArrayPort
property.configure: An input port that accepts a string array of file names for the raster files to be added.

property.name: macroString
description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Dan Higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The IJMacro actor runs ImageJ macros, which are used to display, edit, analyze, process, save, and print a wide variety of images. For more information about ImageJ, see http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/.

The actor accepts a string representing an image file name via the input port or the fileOrURL parameter. The actor will perform the macro specified in the macroString parameter. By default, the actor will open the specified image.

The ImageJ menu toolbar, which appears when the actor opens a specified image, can be used to create additional macros. Select "Plugins > Macros > Record" from the ImageJ menu to create a new macro that can be used by the actor.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts a string representing the path of an image

property.name: prop:fileOrURL
property.configure: The file name or URL of an image to process. The file name may also be input through the input port.

property.name: prop:macroString
property.configure: The ImageJ macro to execute. The macro may include the expression "_FILE_", which will be replaced by the path of the specified image file.

property.configure:
The Display actor reads tokens of any type via its input multiport, and displays each token on a separate line in a text display window.

Specify the size of the text display window with the rowsDisplayed and columnsDisplayed parameters. Simply resizing the window onscreen does not persistently change the size when the workflow is saved, closed, and then re-opened.

If the input is a string token, then the actor strips the surrounding quotation marks before displaying the value.

Select the suppressBlankLines parameter to specify that the actor not add blank lines to the display. By default, the actor will add blank lines.

Note: this actor can consume large amounts of memory. It is not advisable to use it to display large output streams.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: A multiport that accepts tokens of any type.

property.name: prop:suppressBlankLines
property.configure: Specify whether the actor should display blank lines (the default) or suppress them.

property.name: prop:rowsDisplayed
property.configure: The vertical size of the display, in rows. The value is an integer that defaults to 10.

property.name: prop:columnsDisplayed
property.configure: The horizontal size of the display, in columns. The value is an integer that defaults to 40.

property.name: prop:title
property.configure: The title of the text display window. If specified, the value will appear in the title bar of the text display window.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Yuhong Xiong, Edward A. Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Ramp actor is the equivalent of the "for loop" in many traditional computer languages. Its parameters include an intial value, the amount the value is incremented each time the actor fires (the 'step'), and the upper limit of the value (the firingCountLimit). The actor outputs an integer each time it is fired.

The actor's output can be used as a counter (increasing or decreasing), or as a parameter used in an incremented workflow. For example, the output of a Ramp actor can be input to an Expression actor to create file names that are unique for each iteration (e.g., 'file1', 'file2', etc.) The Ramp actor is also particularly useful with PN directed workflows where there is no way to set the number of iterations as a Director parameter.

The first time the actor fires, it outputs the value of its init parameter. The increment value, specified with either the step port or parameter, will only be added on the following iteration. To add an increment to the first iteration, use the Accumulator actor.

The actor accepts values of any type that support addition.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the incremented value.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: An input port that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: port:step
property.configure: An input port that accepts the amount by which the output is incremented on each iteration. The port accepts a value of any type that supports addition. The value is an integer and defaults to 1.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The number of iterations that transpire before the actor indicates that it is finished. If firingCountLimit is set to zero, the actor has no limit imposed.

property.name: prop:step
property.configure: The amount by which the output is incremented on each iteration. The port accepts a value of any type that supports addition. The default is the integer 1.

property.name: prop:init
property.configure: The value produced by the Ramp on its first iteration. The default value is the integer 0.

property.configure:
The Constant actor outputs a constant, which is specified by the value parameter. By default, the actor outputs the integer 1.

The actor can be used to output other types of values, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The actor' s output type matches the type of the specified value.

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the specified constant. By default, the output is 1.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the Constant actor. By default, the value is the integer token 1. The value can be set to another type, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The output type matches the type of the value specified here.

property.name: description
property.value:
The Save_Results_in_Zip sub-workflow creates a zip file of the workflow output. The actor receives the file names of the best rulesets that are output by the Calculate Best Rulesets sub-workflow. These rulesets are generated by the GARP algorithm and are used to create or recreate each predicted species distribution. In addition, the workflow uses three Expression actors (I-DataPoints, II-EnvLayerSet2, and II-EnvLayerSet) to specify (respectively) the set of occurrence location points (digir_data_mephitis.dat, in the example), the environmental layer set (IPCC.dxl), and a text file that contains a list of the workflow parameters and their values.

The RExpression actor uses a simple R-script to compile all of the received file handles into a single array. This array is passed to the Zip Files actor, which archives the files and saves the archive to the location specified by the Constant actor. The Zip Files actor outputs the name and path of the archive file, which is displayed by the Display actor.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins

property.name: Best_Rulesets_array (port)
property.value: This port accepts an array of the GARP ruleset files used to generate the predicted species' distributions. Rules are based on the sampled environmental layer sets, e.g., "If annual precipitation is more than 5 mm and less than 12 mm then the species is present."

property.name: text
property.value:
This ENM sub-workflow creates an archived version of the workflow output. The workflow bundles and then zips the best ruleset files, the source occurrence location file, and the environmental layer data (*.dxl), as well as the parameters used by the workflow (e.g., the number of iterations and number of best rulesets). The zipped file is saved to the directory and file specified by the Constant actor.
For more information, double-click the Documentation button, or right-click the Workflow canvas and select "Documentation" from the drop-down menu.

property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.name: prop:italic
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: prop:bold
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be bold. By default, type will not be bold.

property.name: prop:textColor
property.configure: The font color. Specify a string representing an array of four elements: red, green, blue, and alpha, where alpha is transparency. The default is an opaque black, {0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0}

property.name: prop:textSize
property.configure: The font size. Select an integer from the drop-down menu or specify a new size by typing it directly into the value field. The default is 14.

property.name: prop:text
property.configure: The text of the annotation.

The RExpression actor runs an R script or function. Input and output port are created by the user and correspond to R variables used in the specified R script. The actor outputs the result of the evaluated script.

The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

Kepler contains a number of preconfigured R-actors: Barplot, Boxplot, Scatterplot, Summary, RandomNormal, RandomUniform, Correlation, LinearModel, Regression, RMean, RMedian, RQuantile, and SummaryStatistics.

property.name: port:graphicsFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the file name of the generated graph of the results.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: prop:Rcwd
property.configure: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: prop:displayGraphicsOutput
property.configure: Select to display the plot once the actor has generated it.

property.name: prop:graphicsFormat
property.configure: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: prop:numXPixels
property.configure: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:numYPixels
property.configure: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: prop:graphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: prop:save_nosave
property.configure: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SDF Director is often used to oversee fairly simple, sequential workflows in which the director can determine the order of actor invocation from the workflow. Types of workflows that would run well under an SDF Director include processing and reformatting tabular data, converting one data type to another, and reading and plotting a series of data points. A workflow in which an image is read, processed (rotated, scaled, clipped, filtered, etc.), and then displayed, is also an example of a sequential workflow that requires a director simply to ensure that each actor fires in the proper order (i.e., that each actor executes only after it receives its required inputs).

The SDF Director is very efficient and will not tax system resources with overhead. However, this efficiency requires that certain conditions be met, namely that the data consumption and production rate of each actor in an SDF workflow be constant and declared. If an actor reads one piece of data and calculates and outputs a single result, it must always read and output a single token of data. This data rate cannot change during workflow execution and, in general, workflows that require dynamic scheduling and/or flow control cannot use this director. Additionally, the SDF Director has no understanding of passing time (at least by default), and actors that depend on a notion of time may not work as expected. For example, a TimedPlotter actor will plot all values at time zero when used in SDF.

By default, the SDF Director requires that all actors in its workflow be connected. Otherwise, the director cannot account for concurrency between disconnected workflow parts. Usually, a PN Director should be used for workflows that contain disconnected actors; however, the SDF Director's allowDisconnectedGraphs parameter may also be set to true. The SDF Director will then schedule each disconnected "island" independently. The director cannot infer the sequential relationship between disconnected actors (i.e., nothing forces the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another). However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF model indicate an error.

Because SDF Directors schedule actors to fire only after they receive their inputs, workflows that require loops (feeding an actor's output back into its input port for further processing) can cause "deadlock" errors. The deadlock errors occur because the actor depends on its own output value as an initial input. To fix this problem, use a SampleDelay actor to generate and inject an initial input value into the workflow.

The SDF Director determines the order in which actors execute and how many times each actor needs to be fired to complete a single iteration of the workflow. This schedule is calculated BEFORE the director begins to iterate the workflow. Because the SDF Director calculates a schedule in advance, it is quite efficient. However, SDF workflows must be static. In other words, the same number of tokens must be consumed/produced at every iteration of the workflow. Workflows that require dynamic control structures, such as a BooleanSwitch actor that sends output on one of two ports depending on the value of a 'control', cannot be used with an SDF Director because the number of tokens on each output can change for each execution.

Unless otherwise specified, the SDF Director assumes that each actor consumes and produces exactly one token per channel on each firing. Actors that do not follow the one-token-per-channel firing convention (e.g., Repeat or Ramp) must declare the number of tokens they produce or consume via the appropriate parameters.

The number of times a workflow is iterated is controlled by the director's iterations parameter. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

The amount of data processed by an SDF workflow is a function of both the number of times the workflow iterates and the value of the director's vectorizationFactor parameter. The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

The SDF Director has several advanced parameters that are generally only relevant when an SDF workflow contains composite components. In most cases the period, timeResolution, synchronizeToRealTime, allowRateChanges, timeResolution, and constrainBufferSizes parameters can be left at their default values.

For more information about the SDF Director, see the Ptolemy documentation (http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign3-domains/ptIIdesign3-domains.pdf).

property.name: prop:allowDisconnectedGraphs
property.configure: Specify whether to allow disconnected actors in the workflow (by default, all actors are required to be connected). If disconnected actors are permitted, the SDF Director will schedule each disconnected 'island' independently. Nothing "forces" the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another. However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF workflow indicate an error.

property.name: prop:allowRateChanges
property.configure: Specify whether dynamic rate changes are permitted or not. By default, rate changes are not permitted, and the director will perform a check to disallow such workflows. If the parameter is selected, then workflows that require rate parameters to be modified during execution are valid, and the SDF Director will dynamically compute a new schedule at runtime. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:timeResolution
property.configure: The time precision used by this director. All time values are rounded to the nearest multiple of this number. The value is a double that defaults to "1E-10" (which is 10-10). This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:constrainBufferSizes
property.configure: Specify whether buffer sizes are fixed. By default, buffers are fixed, and attempts to write to the buffer that cause the buffer to exceed its scheduled size result in an error. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

property.name: prop:vectorizationFactor
property.configure: The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

property.name: prop:synchronizeToRealTime
property.configure: Specify whether the execution should synchronize to real time or not. By default, the director does not synchronize to real time. If synchronize is selected, the director will only process the workflow when elapsed real time matches the product of the period parameter and the iteration count. Note: if the period parameter has a value of 0.0 (the default), then selecting this parameter has no effect. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:period
property.configure: The time period of each iteration. The value is a double that defaults to 0.0, which means that the director does not increment workflow time. If the value greater than 0.0, the actor will increment workflow time each time it fires. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: _windowProperties
property.value: {bounds={38, 30, 1259, 794}, maximized=false}

property.name: description
property.value:
This Ecological Niche Model (ENM) workflow predicts the distribution of multiple species based on collected occurrence points and environmental data (IPCC climate data and Hydro1 topographical data). The workflow uses the GARP (Genetic Algorithm for Rule Set Production) algorithm to generate predictions, which are then tested for accuracy. The most accurate predictions are used to project the species' distribution onto a complete map of North and South America. Predictions are made using both historical and future IPCC climate data.

Species' occurrence data is passed to the workflow by the Get Species/Location information sub-workflow. The data is passed to the Calculate Best Rulesets sub-workflow, which reads the occurrence data as well as environmental data used to generate the predicted species distribution. Environmental data must have previously been processed into "bundled" layers that have the same geographic extent and resolution. Occurrence data must be in the form of a set of occurrence points for the species, one occurrence point per line, listed as tab-delimited longitude/latitude combinations. See Ecological Niche Modeling in Kepler for more information about how to prepare data for use with ENM workflows.

The Calculate Best Rulesets sub-workflow uses the GARP algorithm to sample the environmental data and generate predicted species' distributions. GARP is a stochastic algorithm; each time it is run on a given dataset, it will generate a different model. Typically, the algorithm is run hundreds of times for a given species dataset, the results are analyzed to determine the best models, and the results of the best models are compiled and returned. The number_Of_Iterations parameter specifies the number of times to iterate the GARP algorithm, and the NumBest parameter specifies the number of best predictions to select and combine into the final prediction.

The Calculate Best Rulesets actor outputs an array of the best GARP models, which are stored as *.asc grid files. In the example workflow, the GARP algorithm is used to predict species distributions for North and South America, and opening any of the generated *.asc best prediction files with an image processing application, such as ImageJ, will display a map of the Western Hemisphere with the predicted distribution denoted by shades of color.

The AddGrids actor reads the array of best prediction *.asc files and merges them into a single file. Grid cells that have the most predictions of presence across the subset of best models have the highest probability of species occurrence. Thus, cell values are added for all pixels in the input file list. The AddGrids actor outputs the name of the merged file (which is specified via the Output file path and name actor). The IJMacro actor displays the final prediction.

In addition to the array of *.asc files, the Calculate Best Rulesets actor also outputs an array of the rulesets used to generate the predicted species' distributions. The rulesets are generated by the GARP algorithm and are based on the sampled environmental layers. A rule might be something like: "If annual precipitation is more than 5 mm and less than 12 mm then the species is present." Each generated ruleset is saved to a file, and the rulesets used to calculate the best species distributions are output to two places (a relation is used to branch the data): the Save_Results_in_Zip sub-workflow, which zips the files so that they can be easily stored and shared, and the Future_Climate_Models sub-workflow, which generates predicted species' distributions using IPCC future climate change data. For more information about these sub-workflows, right-click the actor icons and select "Documentation."

Any species can be run through this workflow simply by updating the Species_Name parameter with the new species name, and changing the I-DataPoints actor to point to the data file that contains the occurrence points for the new species. To update the I-DataPoints actor, double-click it, and edit the value parameter. Note that the value references DataDirectory, a parameter defined on the Workflow canvas. property("KEPLER") is used to point to the directory in which Kepler is installed.

NOTE: In the interest of minimizing run-times, the example workflow iterates the GARP algorithm only 10 times, which is insufficient for reliable statistics. In addition, only some of the future climate data are processed by the workflow.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins - NCEAS

property.name: SpeciesName (port-parameter)
property.value: The name of the species for which a predicted distribution is being generated.

property.name: numYCells (parameter)
property.value: The number of rows in each environmental layer. All of the environmental layers (climate data, topographic data, mask files, etc) must have the same extent and resolution.

property.name: omissionFraction (parameter)
property.value: Errors of omission occur when a species is present but the model predicts it to be absent. These errors are reported as the proportion of errors to total samples run. The omisssionFraction specifies an acceptable error ratio. Any model that has an omission error above the "cutoff" is disqualified.

property.name: cellSize (parameter)
property.value: The resolution of each environmental layer (climate data, topographic data, mask file, etc). The default value is .5 degrees. All of the environmental layers used in the workflow must have the same extent and resolution.

property.name: numXCells (parameter)
property.value: The number of columns in each environmental layer. All of the environmental layers (climate data, topographic data, mask files, etc) must have the same extent and resolution.

property.name: fractionTestPoints (parameter)
property.value: Model validation requires that some portion of the known species occurrence points be used to test the predictive accuracy of the generated model. An accurate test depends on those points not being used to generate the model, and standard modeling practice is to divide occurrence points into two sets: a set that will be used to "train" the model, and a second set that will be used to test it. The fractionTestPoints parameter specifies the fraction of occurrence points to use in the test set.

property.name: numBestRulesets (parameter)
property.value: The number of best GARP predictions to select and then combine to create the final prediction. Typically, the GARP algorithm is run hundreds of times for a given species data set, the results are analyzed to determine the best models, and the number of "best" models specified by this parameter are compiled and returned.

property.name: ConvexHullScaleFactor (parameter)
property.value: A convex hull is the smallest polygon that contains a set of given points, in this case, the list of species occurrence locations. The ConvexHullScaleFactor parameter is used to "grow" or "shrink" the convex hull by the specified amount.

property.name: numIterations (parameter)
property.value: The number of times to iterate the GARP algorithm. GARP is a stochastic algorithm; each time it is run on a given dataset, it will generate a different model. Typically, the algorithm is run hundreds of times for a given species data set. Each iteration requires 10-20 seconds on a typical desktop PC

property.name: longitude_latitude_table (port)
property.value: The species occurrence data, which consist of longitude/latitude values.

property.name: Best_Ruleset_array (port)
property.value: This port outputs an array of the GARP ruleset files used to generate the predicted distributions. Rules are based on the sampled environmental layer sets, and might contain the following logic: "If annual precipitation is more than 5 mm and less than 12 mm then the species is present."

property.name: SpeciesNameOut (port)
property.value: This port outputs the name of the species for which a predicted distribution is being generated.

property.name: Best_ASC_Maps (port)
property.value: This port outputs an array of map files in ASCII grid format (*.asc). Each map is of the entire Western hemisphere, and the predicted species distribution is designated with color.

The Constant actor outputs a constant, which is specified by the value parameter. By default, the actor outputs the integer 1.

The actor can be used to output other types of values, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The actor' s output type matches the type of the specified value.

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the specified constant. By default, the output is 1.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the Constant actor. By default, the value is the integer token 1. The value can be set to another type, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The output type matches the type of the value specified here.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SDF Director is often used to oversee fairly simple, sequential workflows in which the director can determine the order of actor invocation from the workflow. Types of workflows that would run well under an SDF Director include processing and reformatting tabular data, converting one data type to another, and reading and plotting a series of data points. A workflow in which an image is read, processed (rotated, scaled, clipped, filtered, etc.), and then displayed, is also an example of a sequential workflow that requires a director simply to ensure that each actor fires in the proper order (i.e., that each actor executes only after it receives its required inputs).

The SDF Director is very efficient and will not tax system resources with overhead. However, this efficiency requires that certain conditions be met, namely that the data consumption and production rate of each actor in an SDF workflow be constant and declared. If an actor reads one piece of data and calculates and outputs a single result, it must always read and output a single token of data. This data rate cannot change during workflow execution and, in general, workflows that require dynamic scheduling and/or flow control cannot use this director. Additionally, the SDF Director has no understanding of passing time (at least by default), and actors that depend on a notion of time may not work as expected. For example, a TimedPlotter actor will plot all values at time zero when used in SDF.

By default, the SDF Director requires that all actors in its workflow be connected. Otherwise, the director cannot account for concurrency between disconnected workflow parts. Usually, a PN Director should be used for workflows that contain disconnected actors; however, the SDF Director's allowDisconnectedGraphs parameter may also be set to true. The SDF Director will then schedule each disconnected "island" independently. The director cannot infer the sequential relationship between disconnected actors (i.e., nothing forces the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another). However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF model indicate an error.

Because SDF Directors schedule actors to fire only after they receive their inputs, workflows that require loops (feeding an actor's output back into its input port for further processing) can cause "deadlock" errors. The deadlock errors occur because the actor depends on its own output value as an initial input. To fix this problem, use a SampleDelay actor to generate and inject an initial input value into the workflow.

The SDF Director determines the order in which actors execute and how many times each actor needs to be fired to complete a single iteration of the workflow. This schedule is calculated BEFORE the director begins to iterate the workflow. Because the SDF Director calculates a schedule in advance, it is quite efficient. However, SDF workflows must be static. In other words, the same number of tokens must be consumed/produced at every iteration of the workflow. Workflows that require dynamic control structures, such as a BooleanSwitch actor that sends output on one of two ports depending on the value of a 'control', cannot be used with an SDF Director because the number of tokens on each output can change for each execution.

Unless otherwise specified, the SDF Director assumes that each actor consumes and produces exactly one token per channel on each firing. Actors that do not follow the one-token-per-channel firing convention (e.g., Repeat or Ramp) must declare the number of tokens they produce or consume via the appropriate parameters.

The number of times a workflow is iterated is controlled by the director's iterations parameter. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

The amount of data processed by an SDF workflow is a function of both the number of times the workflow iterates and the value of the director's vectorizationFactor parameter. The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

The SDF Director has several advanced parameters that are generally only relevant when an SDF workflow contains composite components. In most cases the period, timeResolution, synchronizeToRealTime, allowRateChanges, timeResolution, and constrainBufferSizes parameters can be left at their default values.

For more information about the SDF Director, see the Ptolemy documentation (http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign3-domains/ptIIdesign3-domains.pdf).

property.name: prop:allowDisconnectedGraphs
property.configure: Specify whether to allow disconnected actors in the workflow (by default, all actors are required to be connected). If disconnected actors are permitted, the SDF Director will schedule each disconnected 'island' independently. Nothing "forces" the director to finish executing all actors on one island before firing actors on another. However, the order of execution within each island should be correct. Usually, disconnected graphs in an SDF workflow indicate an error.

property.name: prop:allowRateChanges
property.configure: Specify whether dynamic rate changes are permitted or not. By default, rate changes are not permitted, and the director will perform a check to disallow such workflows. If the parameter is selected, then workflows that require rate parameters to be modified during execution are valid, and the SDF Director will dynamically compute a new schedule at runtime. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:timeResolution
property.configure: The time precision used by this director. All time values are rounded to the nearest multiple of this number. The value is a double that defaults to "1E-10" (which is 10-10). This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:constrainBufferSizes
property.configure: Specify whether buffer sizes are fixed. By default, buffers are fixed, and attempts to write to the buffer that cause the buffer to exceed its scheduled size result in an error. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:iterations
property.configure: Specify the number of times a workflow is iterated. By default, this parameter is set to "0". Note that "0" does not mean "no iterations." Rather, "0" means that the workflow will iterate forever. Values greater than zero specify the actual number of times the director should execute the entire workflow. A value of 1, meaning that the director will run the workflow once, is often the best setting when building an SDF workflow.

property.name: prop:vectorizationFactor
property.configure: The vectorizationFactor is used to increase the efficiency of a workflow by increasing the number of times actors fire each time the workflow iterates. If the parameter is set to a positive integer (other than 1), the director will fire each actor the specified number of times more than normal. The default is 1, indicating that no vectorization should be performed. Keep in mind that changing the vectorizationFactor parameter changes the meaning of a nested SDF workflow and may cause deadlock in a workflow that uses it.

property.name: prop:synchronizeToRealTime
property.configure: Specify whether the execution should synchronize to real time or not. By default, the director does not synchronize to real time. If synchronize is selected, the director will only process the workflow when elapsed real time matches the product of the period parameter and the iteration count. Note: if the period parameter has a value of 0.0 (the default), then selecting this parameter has no effect. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

property.name: prop:period
property.configure: The time period of each iteration. The value is a double that defaults to 0.0, which means that the director does not increment workflow time. If the value greater than 0.0, the actor will increment workflow time each time it fires. This is an advanced parameter that can usually be left at its default value.

The Make Directory sub-workflow creates a new local directory and outputs its path. The name of the new directory is specified with the DirectoryMaker actor's directoryName parameter. The value of the actor's parameter references the DirName parameter, which is defined on the Workflow canvas: DataDirectory+"/mephitis". DataDirectory is defined in the top-level workflow, and its value (property("KEPLER")+"/outreach/resources/data/garp") is passed down to the sub-workflow:. Note that 'property("KEPLER")' refers to the directory in which Kepler has been installed.

After the actor creates the new directory, it outputs a "trigger" (the name of the directory) to let the containing workflow know that it has completed its task.

property.name: text
property.value:
The Calculate ConvexHull Mask sub-workflow creates a convex hull, which is the smallest polygon that contains a set of given points, in this case, the list of species occurrence locations. The convex hull is used to mask geographic areas where the species has not been collected (regardless of whether the area is a suitable habitat or not). Any point outside the convex hull is given the value "No_Value."
The mask is used to help generate species "absence" points, which are required by the statistical technique used to evaluate each GARP prediction. Because absence points are rarely available, particularly in broad scale studies, pseudo-absence points are randomly generated as substitutes. These points must be chosen from within the broad range of the species in order to represent environmental information relevant to the model. When the geographic extent to be modeled predicatively is much larger than the extent of the known species range, a mask is used to specify the area from which pseudo-absence points can be selected.
For more information, double-click the Documentation button, or right-click the Workflow canvas and select "Documentation" from the drop-down menu.

property.name: description
property.value:
The Calculate ConvexHull Mask sub-workflow creates a convex hull, which is the smallest polygon that contains a set of given points, in this case, the list of species occurrence locations. The convex hull is used to mask geographic areas where the species has not been collected (regardless of whether the area is a suitable habitat or not). Any point outside the convex hull is given the value "No_Value."

The mask is used to help generate species "absence" points, which are required by the statistical technique used to evaluate each GARP prediction. Because absence points are rarely available, particularly in broad scale studies, pseudo-absence points are randomly generated as substitutes. These points must be chosen from within the broad range of the species in order to represent environmental information relevant to the model. When the geographic extent to be modeled predicatively is much larger than the extent of the known species range, a convex hull mask is used to specify the area from which pseudo-absence points can be selected.

The sub-workflow requires as input a text file containing species occurrence data; data consist of one set of occurrence points per line, formatted as tab-delimited longitude/latitude combinations. The containing workflow passes the name of the occurrence data file to the sub-workflow via the LocationFile port.

The Convex Hull actor constructs the convex hull (i.e., the smallest polygon that contains the given points). If desired, the constructed polygon can be scaled (made larger or smaller) by a user-defined multiplication factor. The factor is specified as a parameter in the containing workflow (ConvexHullScaleFactor, which is initially set to 1).

The actor saves the points that define the convex hull to file name provided by the Hull Data File Name actor, DataDirectory +"/HullPoints.txt". DataDirectory is a parameter defined at the top level of the workflow (the value is property("KEPLER")+"/outreach/resources/data/garp").

The name and path of the convex hull file are passed to the CV Hull to Raster actor, which creates and saves a mask file with the correct resolution and extent. The resolution and extent are specified via the actor's parameters. Note that the values for the cellsize, numrows, and numcols parameters refer to values defined and passed by the containing workflow. The values are initially set to .5, 360, and 720 respectively.

The CV Hull to Raster actor writes the mask file to the location specified specified by the Raster Data File Name actor (DataDirectory+"/mask1.asc") and outputs the mask file name. The ASC to RAW actor then converts the *.asc mask to the binary format required by GARP (*.raw) and passes the file name of the converted mask file to an Expression actor.

The Expression actor is used as a "trigger". Once it receives the name of the mask file (i.e., the Calculate ConvexHull Mask sub-workflow has completed processing), the Expression actor outputs the name of the occurrence point data set, which is output to the containing workflow.

Note: The mask file must be specified within the *.dxl file that summarizes the layer set. Since the source IPCC1.dxl file used by the workflow already references a layer called "mask1.raw," the ASC to Raw actor simply overwrites that existing file with the new mask. Also note that the IPCC.dxl file, which is included in the data directory as well, is identical to the IPCC1.dxl file except that it does not contain the convex hull mask. The IPCC.dxl data include the entire Western hemisphere, and are used when projecting the model (created using the more limited area specified by the mask in the IPCC1.dxl file) to all of North and South America.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins

property.name: LocationFile (port)
property.value: The file name and path of a text file containing species occurrence data; data consist of one set of occurrence points per line, formatted as tab-delimited longitude/latitude combinations.

property.name: output (port)
property.value: An output port that broadcasts the file name and path of the occurrence data.

property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Xiaojun Liu, Edward A. Lee, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Expression actor evaluates a specified expression (e.g., an addition or multiplication operation), which may reference the values of user-specified input ports, the current time, or the actor's iteration count. The actor outputs the value of the evaluated expression.

Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language via the expression parameter. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf.

By default, the expression parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

Input ports are created by the user and correspond to variables used in the specified expression. Currently, the Expression actor does not support input multiports. The actor requires all of its inputs to be present. If inputs are not all present, then the actor will generate an error.

Note: the Expression actor can be used instead of many of the arithmetic actors, such as AddSubtract, MultiplyDivide, and TrigFunction. However, those actors will be usually be more efficient, and sometimes more convenient to use.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the value of the evaluated expression. The actor automatically determines the type based on the type of the input.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: An expression to evaluate. Expressions are specified in the Ptolemy expression language. For more information about the expression language, see http://ptolemy.eecs.berkeley.edu/papers/05/ptIIdesign1-intro/ptIIdesign1-intro.pdf. By default, the parameter is empty, and attempting to execute the actor without first specifying an expression generates an error. Expressions can refer to the values of inputs by the port name; to the current time by the identifier "time"; and to the current iteration count by the identifier "iteration."

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Dan higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The CVHullToRaster actor reads a list of (x,y) points representing a convex hull polygon. The actor creates a "mask": points within the convex hull are set to a value of 1 and points outside the hull have a value of "NO_DATA." The actor saves the mask and outputs it as a raster file.

The hullFileName port accepts a a space-delimited text file containing one pair of (x,y) convex hull points per line. The ConvexHull actor can be used to generate this input file. Use the rasterFileName input port to specify a name for the output raster file.

The size and resolution of the generated raster file can be specified with the numRows, numCols, xllCorner, yllCorner, and cellSize parameters.

property.name: port:rasterFileResult
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the path of the generated raster file, which the actor creates and saves in *.asc format.

property.name: port:rasterFileName
property.configure: An input port that accepts a name to be given to the output raster file.

property.name: port:hullFileName
property.configure: An input port accepting a space-delimited text file containing (x,y) convex hull data points (one pair of points per line).

property.name: prop:numrows
property.configure: An integer representing the number of rows for the raster.

property.name: prop:yllcorner
property.configure: A double token representing the y-value of the lower-left corner of the raster. If the parameter is empty, the y-value is set to the minimum y in the convex hull.

property.name: prop:xllcorner
property.configure: A double token representing the x-value of the lower-left corner of the raster. If the parameter is empty, the x-value is set to the minimum x in the convex hull.

property.name: prop:numcols
property.configure: An integer representing the number of columns for the raster.

property.name: prop:useDisk
property.configure: A Boolean setting to determine whether or not to use a disk for storing data rather than putting all data in RAM arrays during processing. This option in much slower but allows for very large raster files.

property.name: prop:cellsize
property.configure: A double token representing the cell size used by the raster (assumed square). If the parameter is empty, the actor automatically generates a raster with 50 x-direction cells, and y-direction cells to match the y-extent of the convex hull.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: unknown

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The ASCToRaw actor converts ASCII raster files (*.asc) to binary files (*.raw) that can be used as environmental layers (e.g., climate, rainfall, or temperature) in GARP.

GARP is a genetic algorithm that creates an ecological niche model representing the environmental conditions where a species would be able to maintain populations. For more information about GARP, see http://www.lifemapper.org/desktopgarp/.

The ASCToRaw actor receives either an array of ASCII file names or a single ASCII file to convert (via the inputAscFilenameArrayPort or singleFileNamePort input port respectively.) If a single file is specified, the actor outputs the name of the converted binary file. If an array of files is specified, the actor outputs the name of an XML file (*.dxl) that is used by GARP to summarize a layer list. The actor creates the *.dxl file in addition to converting and saving the input files.

property.name: port:outputValuesPort
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a *.dxl file name (if an array of ASCII file names is input via the inputAscFilenameArrayPort) or a single binary file name (if a single ASCII file is input via the singleFilenamePort).

property.name: port:singleFilenamePort
property.configure: An input port that accepts a single ASCII file name. If a single file is specified via this port, the actor will convert the file to a binary format that can be used as a GARP spatial layer input. The name of the binary file is output.

property.name: port:inputAscFilenameArrayPort
property.configure: An input port that accepts an array of ASCII raster file names. The ASCII files must have the same extent and number of cells. If an array is specified via this port, the actor will convert each file to a binary format that can be used as a GARP spatial layer. The actor will also create a *.dxl file that summarizes the layer list. The name of the *.dxl file is output.

property.name: prop:outputRawFilename
property.configure: The name of the converted file. The file name is output as a string when a single ASCII file is input via the singleFilenamePort.

property.name: prop:EnvLayerSetTitleParameter
property.configure: The title of the environmental layer set. The specified title is used in the generated *.dxl file.

property.name: prop:scaleRaw
property.configure: The ASCToRaw actor automatically scales ASCII data values so that they fall within the required binary range (0-255). In some cases, it is not desirable to scale the input file (e.g., if the ASCII file already represents data that is in the range of 0-255). Set the scaleRaw parameter to false to prevent data scaling. Note that a false value is ignored if the ASCII range falls outside 0.0 to 255.0.

property.name: prop:EnvLayerSetIdParameter
property.configure: The ID of the environmental layer set. The specified ID is used in the generated *.dxl file.

property.name: prop:dxlFilename
property.configure: The name of the *.dxl file. The *.dxl file name is output as a string when an array of ASCII file names is input via the inputAscFilenameArrayPort.

The Constant actor outputs a constant, which is specified by the value parameter. By default, the actor outputs the integer 1.

The actor can be used to output other types of values, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The actor' s output type matches the type of the specified value.

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the specified constant. By default, the output is 1.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the Constant actor. By default, the value is the integer token 1. The value can be set to another type, e.g., a string (such as "Hello") or a double (such as 1.2). The output type matches the type of the value specified here.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Dan higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The ConvexHull actor reads a set of (x,y) points, calculates the points that define the convex hull (i.e., the smallest polygon that contains the given points), and saves the hull points to a file. The actor outputs the number of points in the convex hull, as well as the name of the file that contains the calculated hull points.

The pointFileName port accepts a set of (x,y) points that are input as a tab-delimited text file. Use the hullFileName input port to specify a name for the generated output file.

The actor uses the value of the scaleFactor parameter to linearly scale the output hull shape from its center. To scale by area (2x the area, 3x the area, etc), set the scaleFactor to the square root of the desired scaling factor. To make a shape with twice the area, set the scale factor to SQRT(2), for example.

Note: if the scaleFactor parameter is empty or not a number, no scaling will be done.

The actor outputs the number of (x,y) pairs contained in the generated hull file via the numHullPoint point, and the name of the convex hull file via the hullFileResult port. Note that the value of the hullFileName input port and the hullFileResult port are the same (the output is used as a trigger).

property.name: port:hullFileResult
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the hull file name (the output is used as a trigger). The value is the same as that of the hullFileName input.

property.name: port:hullFileName
property.configure: An input port that accepts a name to be given to the output convex hull point list file.

property.name: port:pointFileName
property.configure: An input port that accepts a tab-delimited text file containing (x,y) input points.

property.name: port:numHullPoint
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the number of (x,y) pairs in the hull file.

property.name: prop:scaleFactorParameter
property.configure: The actor uses the value of the scaleFactor parameter to linearly scale the output hull shape from its center. To scale by area (2x the area, 3x the area, etc), set the scaleFactor to the square root of the desired scaling factor. For example, to make a shape with twice the area, set the scale factor to SQRT(2).

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Shankar Rao, Steve Neuendorffer

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The Repeat actor reads and repeats a "block" of tokens (i.e., one or more tokens of any type). The actor outputs the block a user-specified number of times.

Specify the block size with the blockSize parameter and the number of times to repeat the block with the numberOfTimes parameter. Note: because the actor reads multiple input tokens at each iteration, it causes a sample rate increase by a factor of numberOfTimes, and hence affects the number of invocations of downstream actors.

property.name: port:input
property.configure: An input port that accepts tokens of any type. Specify the number of tokens to read at each iteration with the blockSize parameter.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the block of tokens the specified number of times. Specify the number of times to repeat the output with the numberOfTimes parameter.

property.name: prop:blockSize
property.configure: The number of tokens in a block. The value is an integer and must be greater than zero. The default is 1.

property.name: prop:numberOfTimes
property.configure: The repetition factor. The value is an integer and must be greater than 0. The default is 2.

property.name: expression
property.value: # Dan Higgins/NCEAS April 7, 2005 # df is a table with 3 columns: omission, commission, name of ruleset file # show the table df # now sort by omission value df1 <- df[order(df$omission),] #show the sorted table df1 # calculate the number of rows to consider further numRows = fracOm*length(df1$omission) # if fracOm is too small, use cnt if (numRows<cnt) numRows=cnt # pick the 'best' df2 <- df1[1:numRows,] # now sort by commission df3 <- df2[order(df2$commission),] # show result df3 ll <- length(df3$commission) ll # get indices that represent the middle 50% # for short tables, sart with index 1 and get cnt values minindx <- min(0.25*ll,1) maxindx <- max((0.75*ll),(minindx+cnt)) df4 <- df3[minindx:maxindx,] # show the resulting table df4 # show cnt cnt # create a vector from the dataframe vec <- as.vector(df4$ruleset) # get the 'cnt' best rulesets as a vector bestRulesets <- vec[1:cnt]

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Dan Higgins

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The SummaryStatistics actor accepts an array of values and uses R to calculate their mean, standard deviation, and variance. The actor outputs both a graphical and textual representation of the summary analysis.

The R application must be installed on the local system to use this actor. R is a language and environment for statistical computing and graphics. For more information about R, see http://www.r-project.org/.

The actor performs the analysis and saves a graphic of the results to the Kepler working directory. To view the results, connect an ImageJ actor to the graphicsFileName output port and/or a Display actor to the xmean, xstd, and xvar output port.

property.name: port:x
property.configure: An input port that accepts an array of values to evaluate.

property.name: port:graphicsFileName
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the filename of the JPEG representing the generated results.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a copy of the text output that R generates. As the actor communicates with R to run the R function or script, the output port sends back the response (i.e., the values and statistical outputs).

property.name: port:xstd
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the standard deviation of the input.

property.name: port:xmean
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the mean of the input.

property.name: port:xvar
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the variance of the input.

property.name: prop:Rcwd
property.configure: The 'R' working directory (the home directory by default).

property.name: prop:displayGraphicsOutput
property.configure: Select to display the plot once the actor has generated it.

property.name: prop:graphicsFormat
property.configure: The graphics output format. Currently the actor supports either *.pdf or *.png.

property.name: prop:numXPixels
property.configure: The width of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:numYPixels
property.configure: The height of the output graphic in pixels.

property.name: prop:expression
property.configure: The expression that is evaluated to produce the output.

property.name: prop:graphicsOutput
property.configure: Specify whether or not to create a graphics output port. By default, the actor will create a graphics output port.

property.name: prop:save_nosave
property.configure: Specify whether or not to save the R workspace when R is closed; set to '--save' to retrieve the workspace later in a workflow in another R-actor.

The CreateOmissionCommisssionTable sub-workflow converts the output of the Calculate Omission/Commission sub-workflow into a format that can be read and processed by a custom Rexpression actor.
For more information, double-click the Documentation button, or right-click the Workflow canvas and select "Documentation" from the drop-down menu.

property.configure: The DocViewer attribute renders a clickable documentation icon on the Workflow canvas. Clicking the icon opens the workflow documentation window.

property.name: description
property.value:
The Create Omission/Commisssion Table sub-workflow converts the output of the Calculate Omission/Commission sub-workflow into a format that can be read and processed by a custom Rexpression actor.

The workflow uses three Sequence to Array actors to convert the sequence of data tokens produced by the Calculate Omission/Commission sub-workflow into arrays (one array for omission, another for commission, and a third for rulesets), which are output to a Record Assembler actor.

The Record Assembler actor has three user-defined input ports: commission, omission, and ruleset, which receive the corresponding arrays. The actor assembles the data into a single record, which is output.

A record is a composite data type consisting of one or more elements. Each element is named and can have a distinct type. For example, {number=1, name="dog"} is a record containing two elements. The first element, named "number", contains an integer value. The second element, named "name", contains a string value. The record output by the Record Assembler actor consists of the name of the value (e.g., omission) and an array of its values.

The sub-workflow outputs the compiled data to the VI - GARP_BestSubset_R actor, which is a custom RExpression actor that reads the table and selects the best models based on a comparison of omission and commission errors.

property.name: author
property.value: Dan Higgins

property.name: omissionValue (port)
property.value: An input port that accepts the calculated omission errors. Errors of omission occur when a species is present but the model predicts it to be absent. The error is specified as the percentage of errors to total testing points.

property.name: commissionValue (port)
property.value: An input port that accepts the calculated commission errors. Errors of commission occur when a species is predicted to be present but is really absent. Because absence points are randomly generated (pseudo-absence), a commission error may not truly be an error (the model has no way of knowing if the species is really present or not). Since there is no way to calculate true commission error based on pseudo-absence points, a more general method is used: the commission error for each model is the proportion of predicted species presence area to the total area. Very high or very low proportions are more likely to be erroneous.

property.name: rulesetValue (port)
property.value: An input port that accepts the rulesets created by the GARP algorithm, which are used to generate each predicted species distribution.

property.name: Commission_Omission_Record (port)
property.value: An output port that broadcasts a record token containing the omission, commission, and ruleset data.

property.configure:
The RecordAssembler actor receives tokens of various types on user-defined input ports and assembles those tokens into a record, which it outputs. The actor reads and converts one token from each port every time it fires.

A record is a composite data type consisting of one or more elements. Each element is named and can have a distinct type. For example, {number=1, name="dog"} is a record containing two elements. The first element, named "number", contains an integer value. The second element, named "name", contains a string value.

The name of each record element generated by the actor is the name of the input port from which the value was received. An actor customized to use three input ports named "day", "week", "month" could output the following record {day="Monday", week=5, month=12}.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts the generated records.
